    {
      "uuid": "a7b73512-6185-4cdb-97f2-7fcb7da574de",
      "contentType": "question",
      "creatorUserId": "",
      "createdAt": 1437522787591,
      "anonymous": true,
      "submitted": true,
      "viewable": true,
      "karma": 3,
      "title": "Probability Practice",
      "body": "The probability of a transistor failing between months \\(t \u003d a\\) and \\(t \u003d b\\) is given by the probability density function \\(p(t) \u003d ce^{-ct}\\), where this formula is valid for all \\(t \\ge 0\\) and \\(p(t) \u003d 0\\) for all \\(t \u003c 0\\).\n\na. If the probability of the transistor failing in the first 6 months is 0.1, what is the value of \\(c\\)?\nb. Suppose that for a different transistor, the value of \\(c\\) is known to be \\(c \u003d 0.05\\). For this \\(c\\) value, find the mean time it takes for a transistor to fail.\nc. For the same \\(c\\)-value (\\(c \u003d 0.05\\)), find the median time it takes for a transistor to fail. ",
      "allAnswers": [],
      "tags": "definite, improper, integrals, area, length, antiderivatives, converges, diverges, probability",
      "url": "/question/a7b73512-6185-4cdb-97f2-7fcb7da574de",
      "source": "Active Calc 6.6.1",
      "topic": "Calculus/Integral Calculus/Basics of Integration/Properties of Integral"
    },
    {

  ],
  "textContent": [
    {
      "uuid": "8ec592d1-d036-4839-b374-93d6d4643f72",
      "contentType": "textContent",
      "creatorUserId": "",
      "createdAt": 1437611523219,
      "anonymous": true,
      "submitted": true,
      "viewable": true,
